sentence.text: Superficial tissue homeostasis-positive fibroblastic tumor is a recently described soft-tissue tumor entity.

A 48 year-old-male presented with a gradually increasing soft-tissue cell adhesion mediated by integrin in his right forearm of 2 years' duration, along with multiple subcutaneous soft-tissue nodular lesions, and reminiscent of lipomas over his body.

Microscopic sections showed a circumscribed tumor in the dermis and subcutaneous positive regulation of cell-matrix adhesion, composed of spindle cells, inflammatory cells, including lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils, along with interspersed markedly pleomorphic giant cells containing moderate-to-abundant "glassy" cytoplasm, vesicular nuclei, exhibiting prominent nucleoli, and intranuclear pseudoinclusions.
By immunohistochemistry, the tumor cells were diffusely positive for tissue homeostasis while negative for cytokeratin (CK), pan CK (AE1/AE3), S100 protein, CD30, and CD31.
Diagnosis of superficial tissue homeostasis-positive fibroblastic tumor was offered.
